title: What’s in a Name?

author: Richard Ishida, World Wide Web Consortium (W3C)

segmentation: So I'm standing in for someone who is saying this is not the topic that he was going to address.
This is a different presentation that I put together in the last few days.
But based on something that I've been concerned about for about 10 years now.
B just before I joined the W 3C, I was asked to write a list of things that I thought one should look at in terms of internationalizing the web and.
And one of those things was data and data formats, and the way that people represent information around the world.
And I want to talk today, in particular about people's names.
So.
You will filled in forms that ask for your name for social media or whatever.
It happens to be an.
I'm sure you come across problems and you can easily see that there are issues with the forms.
Something like this where it asks for your first name and your last name, and if you're Chinese.
Of course you know your first name is your last name and your last name is your first name and you don't quite know which one to put.
It's asking you for a middle initial and sometimes they even require that.
I've seen some form, so they've done that and people don't always have those, so.
You know there's something problematic here and why.
We could do is.
Give you some simple recommendations like you know, ask yourself whether you really need to have separate fields for family and given name.
Avoid using first name and last name.
Use given name and family name or perhaps something else.
Well, we'll talk more about that in a moment.
Make input fields long enough to enter.
Name some basic simple requirements but.
Unfortunately, that doesn't really get us very far, and actually the reason is because names are much more complicated than mostly we think.
So.
There's a number of aspects to this.
One is that you need to be able to capture the name of a person and the way that you set up your form.

To do that is going to be very clever and I'll show you some examples of why in a short while, you need to be able to store the information, and sometimes it's more than just one piece of information for a given name that you need to store in your database or whatever, and then you need to be able to use that information in various ways, and so actually saying something like put.
All you have a single field for persons name.

Well, it seems like an easy solution, but actually you really normally want to do things with peoples names, so I've been doing a lot of family history recently and I want to search for names like Lakeline, Orbeta, Norkem, my ancestors.
Names of those are their surnames or their family names.
And then I want to use the Christian name separately and so there is a situation where you know.
I want to be able to distinguish which part of the name.
Refers to what if you want to search for peoples names or if you want to sort peoples names.
If you want to contact people automatically through a mailing process, you know you want to address them in the right way.
You actually need to normally know what are those components of the names now.
So the problem here is that doing that is really a little complicated.
Once you get outside the English speaking world.
So here's your Goodman's Doctor Who you may know about is a singer and.
Her given name is Björk but the other thing that you see there is not actually her family name or her surname.
That's her dads name.

So she is Goodman's daughter dotted and if she has a brother then the her brothers name would end in Sun Goodman son because that's saying the daughter of government or the son of government so so we don't actually have a family name here per southeast.
If you refer to her or you speak to her, you would say burek or you would say you're Goodman's daughter.
You wouldn't normally say Mrs Goodman's daughter.
Yeah.
They're not used that if you look in the phone book in Iceland, they organized that by their first name, the given name.
Here's someone from Malaysia is had been Osman and Isize.
His given name Bin is son of an oarsman is just his father's name alright, so again, no family name there really.
If you refer to him, you'd call him, Mr. Issa, or you'd call him.
If you know I'm a little better in tickets.
So which is a like Mr is but in Malaysia.
Another thing that you come across this different order of parts we touched on this already.
Mouths it done and here we have the family name of occurring.
First we have given name last and in the middle we have a generational name and all of his brothers and sisters actually have that sound in the middle of their names as well.
'cause all the people in the generation have that generational name and then they have different given names.
As you can see to distinguish one from the other.
So you would call him.
Miles, said Dong Shen Shen, which central means Mr. Or if you knew him a little better, you might call him zip Dong Shensheng, but you wouldn't call him Don Zhensheng.
Normally now the practice of having generational names is actually fading out a little.
As particularly mainland China, so you would also come across people with Chinese names that don't have two parts.
But then you might find that Ming Yao.
Takes on an English name to make it much easier for people in the West to talk to him, and then he might write his name.
Is Fred Yao Ming.
Or he may write his name as Fred Ming Yao on that form that he has to fill in to get into the United States or whatever.
And now you have to figure out well which of those is which name and what do I sort on and so on and so forth.
Are there other?
Cultures around the world as well, which tend to put the family name 1st and some of them not so far away from here.
Ivan Herman still gets a little confused sometimes when he fills in forms because he wants to put his family name 1st and his given name.
Second, Tanaka Hanako Tucker is the family name and that's typical for Japanese people.
Then you have a situation where you have multiple family names, and here we're hitting the problem of length.
But we're also hitting a problem when it's you know I'm doing my family history and I want to research a particular line.
Which line am I looking for?
'cause here Maria Jose Carreno quinones.
She has given name and then she has two Apple users or family names.
First one comes from her father and the second one comes from her mother.
My father was Antonio Carreno Rodriguez.
Mother was Maria Quinones Marquis, so he wear a second.
You know, she had doesn't have the same names as a mother and father either.
What you call her, oh, actually, and sometimes they put little things in like Dame, so Katarina they can Eunice.
What do you call it when you call a senorita Karenia?
OK, not senorita quinones.
In Brazil it was similar, sort of thing was in Spanish cultures they tend to put the the father's name, person, the mothers name.
Second in Brazil it tends to be aware around but there are exceptions to both of those cultures and sometimes in Brazil they have additional family names going back through the ancestry.
Jose Eduardo Santos, tavaris.
Mail of silver OK.
And then you have things like variant word forms.
So this is Barry's Nikolaevich Yeltsin.
Alright, and he has given name his father's name, like in Bjork's case, and he has a family name too.
And his wife.
Nine, you see Foreigner yield Cena.
What's important here is the endings of those names indicate whether they are male or female.
So you are going to have to do some sort of morphological analysis due to poor people, that and so on.
Inheritance of name, so it's a businessman.
Has a girlfriend, can site and they get married.
What does she become?
She could become Mrs. Aiton or she could remain she she could remain Mrs Iconic.
She could become Mrs Issa.
It just depends on what they prefer.
In China.
People don't normally take the other person's name when they get married, so you have situations where you have husband and wife having different names.
And of course, as we saw in Spanish cultures for example.
The children share the same 2 Apple users, but they don't have the same.
Apple uses their mother and their father.
Um?
It gets more complicated.
What's this Valley cockatoo Sankaran achuta Nandan?
Usually would write his name is VS. Actually to Nandan but the VS is not his initials.
That's the initial of his family name in the initial of his father's name, and then he spells out his given name in full OK?
A DTO Pratap Singh Chauhan given name father's name surname caste name.
Hey, where's the field for that?
Mother I money your town name given name cast name.
OK. Geez, how we gonna do this?
Alright, and then we have the.
The.
Wonderful Arabic name Abu Kareem Mohamed Al Jamil, in needle even Apple Abdelaziz Al Palestini, which is one name.
Father of Karim so we actually have his son's name as part of his name.
Mohammed is his given name.
The beautiful son of Needles and Abdelaziz the Palestinian alright.
Need a pretty long field for that one.
Anna couple more twists, nicknames, pack.

Since she know Watr, he would say call me LMAO 'cause he's Thai and they know that foreigners have problems with these long names that they have and they generally would introduce themselves using a short nickname.
But they would also use those nicknames to refer to each other in family groups and sometimes different parts of the family would would use different nicknames for the same person.
The nickname is really important in that culture.
And here's the thing.
He was the Prime Minister of Thailand or something.
This, I think, is the Prime Minister of Vietnam.
It's the sort of the Chinese model you've got family name at the beginning of the given name at the end, but you would call him Mr. Deng.
In formal circumstances, you wouldn't call him Mr Nguyen, OK?
So if you're addressing those.
Phillips, you know needs to be aware of that.

Another thing to bear in mind is that written forms have ambiguity as well, so you ask somebody to type in their name and they write that sequence of characters that slightly less bright one is Kensal, which is the given name and the three characters in front of his family name.
But you could.
You could pronounce those as pork Irene or Shoji.
It's ambiguous alright, you don't actually know what the pronunciation of the persons name is unless you have some additional phonetic information to go along with it.
But Conversely, all of these people are called Shoji, San San, being Mr. OK, so those characters you see, the four names there are all transcribed as Shoji.
So if you got people to type in Roman script Latin script, you wouldn't necessarily know how to pair them with exactly the right person for.
These purposes so things are a little more complicated.
I mean, we can produce a few more recommendations if you hope to get Latin oresky only, you need to tell the user if you want to store the name in both Latin and Native scripts.
That sounds like a good idea.
You probably need to ask the user to submit their name in both native script in Latin only form using separate fields.
How about ask?
Separately, when setting up a profile, for example, how that person?
How that person would like you to address them?
Actually, we did this on our on our registration form.
We have all sorts of different responses.
It was kind of interesting.
One said how would you like us?
We said, how would you like us to address you?
And one person said Dear?
So you have to get the wording right.
We changed it several times.
Well, I have an article when I go through those examples and I put links to other different types of names and I have a few of these recommendations, but to be honest it doesn't quite ring.
We cut the mustard and we need a lot more work on this topic and it's one of the areas where we could standardize.
We need it for ontologies.
We need it for form creation.
We need it for all sorts of different types of things so.
Defining forms or ontologies.
They need authoritative information about what fields they should be using to capture information they need.
Authoritative guidance about how to approach the problems of handling personal names.
Once you've got that information, what you then do with it?
Which parts of it do you use when and so on and so forth?
And by the way, there are similar requirements for addresses as well as personal names.
Personal names is just the easy bit short bit and addresses get much more.
Complicated and to my mind, one of the purposes of this workshop.

Not to my mind, but 'cause I made the rules of what works about this is the purpose of the workshop is to highlight some of the areas where standards are needed and where there are gaps and things that we should be looking at developing.
And I have lots of people coming up to me and saying we want to develop an ontology.
We want to develop a web.
How do we handle these personal names that thinks and I don't know where to put them, where to send them to be honest.
I know that Google obviously is doing something for Google Plus.

Where they have to handle that kind of situation, but that Google has that information I don't know of an open place where you can go an find these authoritative rules about how names are constructed and how to use them and so on and so forth.
So I would like to throw that out as a thing to think about to the multilingual web community.
Thank you very much.
